content.webTitle: Moor Mother: Analog Fluids of Sonic Black Holes review – raging protest poetry

fields.headline: Moor Mother: Analog Fluids of Sonic Black Holes review – raging protest poetry
fields.bodyText: Philadelphian poet, activist and musician Moor Mother has gone from the corners of her city’s underground scene to presenting work at high-cultural institutions such as London’s ICA and Barbican, and collaborating with others to make industrial dub as Zonal and wavy club music as 700 Bliss: an intense but sustained flurry of activity that is testament to how keen and lucid her feeling is. On this chilling fourth solo record, she returns to the lie of a post-racial America. Some of her poetry, sometimes verging into rap, could be chanted through a bullhorn at a protest, such as LA92’s “LAPD on PCP, body bag body bag for you and me”, and this pissed-off fervour is bracing. But she’s even more powerful when she’s calm, as on Shadowgrams, where she surveys ongoing evidence of colonialism in the UK, Portgual and elsewhere like an NGO worker. The Myth Hold Weight is one of her best ever tracks, an endlessly spilling rhyme scheme dotted with powerful wisdom: “Don’t let death compliment you / no matter how ugly you feel.” Her backings are stunningly realised: collages of sawing strings, tones of meandering frequency, and drums that gallop like a horse let loose to nowhere. Lurching in the hull of the mix are sampled vocals from across history, snatches of what sound like gospel or field songs. This chaos, perhaps, is the sound of black America trying to haul itself into stability but being gaslighted at every turn. There is a moment of black humour, in every sense, when Paul Robeson suddenly looms into view singing slavery-era spiritual Nobody Knows the Trouble I’ve Seen – coming amid the violent whirl of Moor Mother’s productions, you’re left thinking: no shit. This album announces that the fight for equality is not done, but rages in our ears.
